claims.claim: In preclinical mouse tumor models, an intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 is reported to improve tumor control compared with control conditions.

evidence.quote: - Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.
5. Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors, so efficacy in mice does not guarantee clinical benefit.

claims.claim: In a retrospective metastatic patient cohort treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status is associated with better survival.

evidence.quote: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |

claims.caveat: Because the human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized and vaccination timing varied, the association cannot be interpreted as a definitive causal effect.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination is reported to broaden tumor antigen presentation, increasing the fraction of tumor proteins observed in immunopeptidomics and in the MHC-I peptidome.

evidence.quote: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: The authors propose that intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers type I interferon signaling in tumors, contributing to improved immune priming for checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
| Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |

claims.caveat: The report summarizes a proposed mechanistic chain; without full experimental detail here, the magnitude and generality of interferon induction across models could vary.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling appears necessary for the sensitization effect, because IFNAR1 blockade is reported to eliminate the benefit.

evidence.quote: - Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: This necessity claim is based on a specific perturbation (anti-IFNAR1) described in summary form, and may depend on tumor model context and experimental conditions.
